column4: I. Concept: Force  A. Definition: A push or pull upon an object resulting from the object's interaction with another object.       1. Types of Force              a. Contact Force: Forces that result when the two interacting objects are physically in contact with one another.            - Friction Force            - Spring Force            - Tension Force            - Normal Force            - Applied Force            - Air Resistance Force        b. Non-Contact Force: Forces that result even when the two interacting objects are not in contact with each other, yet are able to affect one another.            - Gravitational Force            - Electrical Force            - Magnetic Force     2. Units of Force: The unit in which force is measured in the SI (international system of units) is the newton (N).     3. Application of Force: The application of a force on an object causes a change in the motion of the object.         4. Laws of Force: Newton's three laws of motion describe the motion of massive bodies and how they interact.        - Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia)        - Newton's Second Law ( Force equals mass times acceleration – F=ma)        - Newton's Third Law (For every action, there's an equal and opposite reaction)  B. Related Concepts           1. Momentum: The product of an object's mass and velocity.     2. Acceleration: The rate of change of velocity over time.     3. Work: Work is done when a force that is applied to an object moves that object.     4. Energy: The capacity to do work.     5. Power: The rate of doing work or of transferring heat.     6. Pressure: The force applied perpendicular to the surface of an object per unit area.    C. Famous Researchers     1. Isaac Newton: English mathematician, physicist, and astronomer known for proposing the three laws of motion.     2. Galileo Galilei: Italian astronomer, physicist and engineer who made significant contributions to the sciences of motion.     3. Albert Einstein: German physicist known for his theory of relativity which addresses the concept of force in terms of energy-momentum.  II. Concept: Impact of Force  A. Definition: The effect or influence that a force has on an object or system.        1. Changing Direction: A force can change the direction of a moving object.      2. Changing Speed: A force can also change the speed of a moving object.      3. Changing Shape: A force can change the shape of an object.      4. Causing Motion: A force can set a stationary object in motion or stop a moving object.       B. Related Concepts            1. Impulse: The change in momentum of an object when the object is subjected to a force for an interval of time.      2. Impact: The high force or shock (mechanics) applied over a short time period.      3. Collision: An event in which two or more bodies exert forces on each other over a relatively short time.      4. Deformation: The change in the shape or size of an object due to an applied force.    C. Famous Researchers      1. Karl Gustav Magnus: German physicist known for his significant contributions regarding the effects of rotating wheels.      2. Robert Hooke: English natural philosopher, architect and polymath renowned for his law of elasticity (Hooke's Law).      3. Leonhard Euler: Swiss mathematician and physicist known for his many influential contributions to mechanics.
